Description: A string composed of a number of tiny 'Conus' shells, two 'Natica' shells, one 'Nerita' shell, two long pointed pendants of ivory and a crouching hawk amulet of ivory. The latter has incised lines, filled with a black material, cut across the shoulders, centre of the body and tail. The widest part of the bird's body is perforated.
Curator's comments: Cf. H. Junker, ‘Bericht über die Grabungen der Akademie der Wissenschaften in Wein auf den Friedhöfen von el-Kubanieh-Süd. Winter 1910-11’ (Vienna, 1919), 108; fig. 58, no. 24; pl. XXXIV; ivory, Predynastic Period. 'Towards the end of the Predynastic Period the falcon in the archaic crouching position occurs in several tombs.' (E. Baumgartel in 'Cambridge Ancient History' I, 3rd Edition (Cambridge, 1970-77), i, 496). Also from this burial: beads (1930,0711.120 & 1930,0711.122), pendants and beads (1930,0711.121). Bibliography: C. Andrews, 'Amulets of Ancient Egypt' (London 1994), 9; G. Brunton, ‘Mostagedda and the Tasian Culture’ (London, 1937), 75, 86; Grave register, pl. XXXI; Bead corpus, pl. XXXIX, 45A3; 89B12; E. Massoulard, ‘Préhistoire et Protohistoire d’ Égypte’ (Paris, 1949), pl. LXVIII, 9.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (98)
